name: rnasplice-disease-splicing
title: RNA Splice: Disease-Associated Splicing Analysis
description: Alternative splicing analysis for disease research. Detects differential splicing events, isoform switches, and splice junction usage between conditions. Ideal for cancer, neurological disorders, and genetic diseases.
content:
RNA Splice: Disease Splicing Analysis

Alternative splicing generates multiple protein isoforms from a single gene. Aberrant splicing drives many diseases including cancer (60% of mutations affect splicing), neurodegeneration, and genetic disorders. This pipeline identifies disease-associated splicing changes.

Why Study Alternative Splicing?

  • Functional Diversity: 95% of human multi-exon genes undergo alternative splicing
  • Disease Mechanisms: Splicing defects in cancer, neurodegeneration, muscular dystrophy
  • Therapeutic Targets: Splice-modulating drugs (e.g., Spinraza for SMA)
  • Biomarkers: Cancer-specific isoforms for diagnostics
  • Drug Response: Isoform switches predict treatment response

Splicing Event Types

  • Exon Skipping (SE): Most common (~40%), exclude/include exons
  • Alternative 5'/3' Splice Sites (A5SS/A3SS): Use different splice boundaries
  • Intron Retention (IR): Retain intron in mature mRNA
  • Mutually Exclusive Exons (MXE): Choose between two exons
  • Alternative First/Last Exon: Different start/end of transcript

Pipeline Workflow

  1. Alignment: STAR 2-pass mode for splice junction discovery
  2. Quantification: Salmon for transcript-level expression
  3. Splicing Analysis: DEXSeq (exon usage), rMATS (events), SUPPA2 (PSI)
  4. DTU Analysis: DRIMSeq, DEXSeq for differential transcript usage
  5. Isoform Switching: IsoformSwitchAnalyzeR detects functional consequences
  6. Visualization: Sashimi plots, isoform structures

Disease Applications

Cancer:

  • BCL-X: Anti-apoptotic (BCL-XL) vs pro-apoptotic (BCL-XS)
  • CD44: Standard vs variant isoforms (metastasis, EMT)
  • FGFR2: IIIb (epithelial) vs IIIc (mesenchymal) in breast cancer
  • MDM2: Full-length (p53 inhibitor) vs truncated variants
  • PKM: PKM1 (normal) vs PKM2 (Warburg effect)

Neurological Disorders:

  • Tau (MAPT): 3R vs 4R isoforms in Alzheimer's, FTD
  • APP: Exon 7/8 splicing in Alzheimer's
  • HTT: Huntingtin splicing modulates toxicity
  • SMN: SMN1 vs SMN2 exon 7 inclusion in spinal muscular atrophy

Genetic Diseases:

  • Spinal Muscular Atrophy: SMN2 exon 7 skipping
  • Myotonic Dystrophy: MBNL1 sequestration → global splicing defects
  • β-Thalassemia: HBB splice site mutations

Splicing Metrics

PSI (Percent Spliced In):

  • Quantifies exon inclusion: PSI = included / (included + skipped)
  • PSI = 0: Always skipped, PSI = 1: Always included
  • ΔPSI > 0.1 typically considered biologically significant

Differential Transcript Usage (DTU):

  • Shifts in isoform proportions (not total expression)
  • Gene-level expression unchanged, but isoform ratios differ

Key Outputs

  • Differential Splicing Events: rMATS results (SE, MXE, A5SS, A3SS, RI)
  • PSI Values: Per-sample exon inclusion levels
  • DTU Results: DRIMSeq, DEXSeq differential transcript usage
  • Isoform Switches: IsoformSwitchAnalyzeR functional predictions
  • Sashimi Plots: Splice junction visualization

Perfect for: Cancer splicing • Neurodegeneration • Genetic diseases • Isoform biomarkers • Therapeutic target discovery
